abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was assessed as
            unsatisfactory with project sustainability unlikely. World
            Bank performance in appraisal was partially satisfactory
            while its performance in supervision was adjudged as
            deficient. As a typical financial intermediation lending
            (FIL) operation, the project offered the following lessons:
            A FIL operation may achieve limited sectoral policy
            objectives if the borrower is committed to the specific
            objectives and does not have many options for mobilizing
            long-term funding sources. FILs are ineffective in
            introducing commercial banking practices to financial
            intermediaries which in reality are government policy banks.
            Sound market analysis of potential long-term funding demand
            in an economy is essential in designing an effective FIL
            operation. While technical assistance in the areas of
            developing a credit manual, accounting procedures, and
            information technology systems are needed, the bottom line
            for a sound sub-loan is market-based, realistic
            sales/revenue projections. Even as a non-lending co-lender,
            The International Development Association should be more
            proactive in project preparation and supervision to ensure
            the cost-effectiveness of the project's economic
            outcomes and of staff inputs.

repnme.cdata!: Tonga - Second Tonga Development Bank Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the project are:
            (a) to capitalize on the recently implemented National
            Reserve Bank (NRB) legislation to implement interest rate
            policy reform; (b) to increase production capacity,
            primarily in the agricultural, industrial, service and
            tourism sectors, by providing long-term resources to the
            Tonga Development Bank (TDB) for making term loans primarily
            to the private sector; and (c) to continue to support
            TDB's (TDB) institutional development. The project
            would be cofinanced by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and
            would comprise a credit line to the TDB to meet the
            term-financing needs of its clients over a three-year
            commitment period, 1990-92. Financing under the line of
            credit would be provided to all viable subprojects in a
            broad range of subsectors.

docna.cdata!: Tonga - Second Tonga Development Bank Project

display_title.display_title:
Tonga - Second Tonga Development
            Bank Project
